definition: to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
Hong Kong, abbr. for 香港[Xiang1 gang3]/surname Gang

sentences.english: The first half of 2006 flights per week to 780 sorties .
sentences.chinese: 2006年上半年每週進出港航班爲780架次。

sentences.english: They said the European Union and the United States are starting to identify illegal fishing ships and bar them from their ports.
sentences.chinese: 稱，歐盟和美國開始鑑別非法捕魚船隻，禁止出港。

sentences.english: At the gate of the departure hall, we have buses to take you to the hotel.
sentences.chinese: 再出港大廳的門口，我們有巴士接你們去賓館。

sentences.english: The dockers loaded the ship overtime so as to send it off Early the next morning.
sentences.chinese: 碼頭工人加班裝船，以便第二天一早就送船出港。

sentences.english: Your present course too close to outbound vessel.
sentences.chinese: 你船現在的航向離出港船太近。

sentences.english: The General Meigs is tiding out of the harbor.
sentences.chinese: 梅格斯將軍號在趁潮出港。

sentences.english: Our first ship won't clear till the end of the month.
sentences.chinese: 我們的第一艘船得到本月底才能出港。

sentences.english: Does your facility have procedures for tracking the timely movement of incoming and outgoing goods?
sentences.chinese: 你們對貨物進出港及時與否有跟蹤程序嗎？

sentences.english: On June 4, Allied fleets set off according to the original plan.
sentences.chinese: 六月四日，按照原定計劃，盟軍艦隊拔錨出港。

definition: to return to the point of departure
scheduled flight/flight number/plane/scheduled sailing/sailing number/passenger ship
home port (of a ship or fleet)
to stop running (of flight of shipping service)/to suspend service (flight, sailing)/to interrupt schedule
